Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 01:10PM JanetM wrote: The waiting is the hardest part of this.  Try to keep busy and think good thoughts.  I had my biopsy just before Memorial Day weekend and had to wait until the following week for results.  I would call the office tomorrow and see if they can tell you when the results will be ready.
Posts.Title: waiting for pathology JennL bdavis

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 10:50AM JanetM wrote: It wouldn't hurt to go to a breast specialist and have the results reviewed.  In addition, you would have made contact with a specialsit should something turn up in the future.  That is what I did and when I needed a lumpectomy I knew who was going to do it and I didn't have to worry about finding someone.
Posts.Title: Should I see a breast specialist? blondie0236 blondie0236

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 03:27PM JanetM wrote: I had a stereotactic biopsy in May after every 6 month follow ups for 3 years.  They saw some changes that needed to be looked at more closely.  The stereotactic biopsy wasn't too bad.  I had to have it done in two areas in the same breast.  The hardest part was laying still for them to get me into the right position each time and to do the procedure.  I didn't really feel too much.  The compression from the mammogram to locate the areas was less than a regular mammogram (at least for me).  They numbed me with lidocaine and I only felt some discomfort from that and then some pressure when they actually did the procedure.  Mine took about 2.5 hours but they were doing to separate areas.  The stereotactic biopsy showed LCIS and ALH.  I needed a lumpectomy after that to make sure that nothing else was going on.  The lumpectomy confirmed the LCIS and ALH but also showed some ADH as well.  I am back on the every 6 month merry go round at least for now.  If you have any other questions please PM me.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 09:54AM JanetM wrote: My lumpectomy required 2 wires to be placed as there were to areas that needed to be taken out through the incision.  My incision is about 2.5 inches long and is on the upper outer portion of my breast.  I went home in a surgical bra, very tight with lots of velcro and stayed in that for about 48 hours and iced it.  It was uncomfortable but not terribly painful, the hardest part was sleeping on my back.  I took it easy for a few days but by the following Monday (6 days later) I was marching in the Memorial Day parade ( a 2 mile walk).

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 04:22PM JanetM wrote: I had a stereotactic biopsy of 2 sites in the same breast back in May.  The procedure itself was not painful, I only felt the few shots of lidocaine and then the pressure each time they took the samples, 12 from each site.  I wore a zip up sweatshirt and went home wrapped tightly in an ace bandage with steristrips covering the two small incisions.  I did take some Xanax before as I knew I would need something to help me relax and stay still for the 2.5 hours that the process took.  I iced the area and kept the ace bandage on until the next morning.  I did go out to a school board meeting that night so it really wasn't a bad experience.
Posts.Title: Finally a biopsy! Kaara JanetM

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 05:31PM JanetM wrote: Kaara, Mine was done by the radiologist.  It was done using mammography and I had to lay on my stomach and be positioned for each biopsy.  Not much fun but not much pain either.  Tylenol was fine for the discomfort afterward.  Wishing you good thoughts.  I go tomorrow for a mammogram, so that should be fun....

Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy-Nervous dlm217 bonbondidit4

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 05:21AM JanetM wrote: The stereotactic biopsy is really not bad.  The worst part is having to stay in one position for an extended period of time.  When I went for my last mammogram, they didn't even send the results to my PCP, the radiologist came and told me what she saw and that I needed the stereotactic biopsy ASAP.  I had the stereotactic biopsy about 10 days later, they wanted to do it sooner but the first date they had was they day before my future daughter in law's bridal shower.  I didn't want to do it the day before so I put it off a few days.   The procedure took about 2.5 hours from start to finish as they had to do 2 sites in the same breast.  I was a little sore and bruised after and went home a rested more from being stiff from being still for so long.  Wishing you good thoughts.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy-Nervous dlm217 bonbondidit4

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 04:23PM JanetM wrote: Take a deep breath and just know that 80% of these things turn out to be nothing.  Did they give you anymore information other than an area of concern?  You can request a copy of the reports so that you can read them for yourself and have a better understanding of what they are actually looking at.  What kind of biopsy are you having on January 6th?  As hard as it may be, try to put this out of your mind and enjoy the holidays with your children and family.  All of us here have been through this horrible waiting game.  Wishing you a good holiday and good thoughts on your biopsy.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 04:28PM JanetM wrote: I had mammogram guided stereotactic core biopsies (2 in same breast) in May.  The procedure was relatively painfree as I was numbed very well for each one.  The only uncomfortable part was laying still for the amount of time (2 hours) that it took to do both sites.  I went home wrapped very tightly in an ace type bandage that I was told to keep on until the next morning.  It did help to take Xanax before I went for the procedure.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 09:22AM JanetM wrote: I was diagnosed with ALH and LCIS on stereotactic core biopsy at age 56 after a number of years of close monitoring (every 6 month mammos and ultrasounds).  Had a lumpectomy in May and also found ADH.  Now I am back on the every 6 month follow up including clinical exams.  My breasts are dense as well.  Right now I have chosen not to take tamoxifen.  After my next mammo, ultrasound and clinical exam I will make some decisions about future surgery, etc.

Posts.Title: steroetactic biopsy scaredycatwoman geebung

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 02:57PM JanetM wrote: Thought I would add my 2 cents here as well.  I have been doing the every 6 month follow up after having a them see something on my first mammo at age 53.  I had a sonogram that was ultimately followed by a sonogram guided fine needle biopsy because it was so close to the chest wall.  Since then I have had a mammo or sono or both every 6 months.  Most recently the mammo showed significant calcifications that resulted in a mammo guided stereotactic core biopsy which showed ALH and LCIS.  Two weeks after the core biopsy I had a lumpectomy which removed ALH and LCIS but also showed ADH.  So now I am scheduled for a new baseline mammo of the busy breast in November and after that I will have to consider the options.  In my last conversation with my breast surgeon she said there's alot going on in there and we will need to follow you closely.   Not sure I like being on this merry-go-round.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 09:57PM JanetM wrote: When I went to the breast surgeon after my first biopsy I brought her all of my films and reports as well as the pathology slides.  She reviewed the films and reports and did her own thorough breast exam.  She concurred with what was seen on the films and had the slides reviewed.  At that point she also concurred that 6 month follow ups were in order.  I continued with 6 month followups including exams, mammograms and ultrasounds for another 2 1/2 years until this year when a 6 month follow up mammogram showed a change including additional calcifications.  I had a stereotactic biopsy that showed LCIS and ALH which was followed by a lumpectomy which removed the LCIS and ALH but also removed some ADH which was not found on the stereotactic biopsy as well as some additional calcifications.  It was comforting to me to have already established a relationship with aa breast surgeon prior to needing the lumpectomy.  It was one less thing to think about when I was already stressed out.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 10:45PM JanetM wrote: I had 2 stereotactic core biopsies done and it really was not too bad.  I would highly recommend getting a prescription for Ativan or Xanax to take before.  It took Xanax before and it took the edge off so that I could lay still while they did it.  I was able to reposition myself in between the biopsies.  In my case it took almost 2.5 hours from start to finish.  They wrapped me up with an ice pack before before I left and I was sore for a day or two afterwards.  Overall it was not a bad experience.
